channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Antigay Laws Gain Global Attention; Countering Them Remains Challenge
item.description: The United States, the European Union and the United Nations have made their advocacy of gay rights clear, but officials question how much they can really do to effect change.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Afghan Broadcaster Says U.S. Soldiers Abused Him
item.description: A radio station has angered the Taliban by broadcasting pro-government ads, but that did not stop American Special Forces from raiding it.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: The Lede: Latest Updates on Ukraine Crisis
item.description: The Lede is following events in Ukraine and Russia on Saturday, following a unanimous vote in the upper house of the Russian Parliament approving a request from President Vladimir Putin to send a military force to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Rubio Proposes Steps U.S. Should Take With Russia
item.description: Russia’s use of its military in Ukraine has given Senator Marco Rubio of Florida an opening to emerge as a new foreign policy voice of the Republican Party.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN

item.title: Pakistani Taliban, Announcing Cease-Fire, Urge the Revival of Peace Talks
item.description: The announcement of the truce came just hours after two bombings killed 13 people and wounded 10 in an attack on a polio vaccination team in the northwestern Khyber region.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: The relative of a security official killed in a roadside bomb attack mourned over his coffin in Jamrud, Pakistan, on Saturday.

item.title: ‘Act of Killing’ Film Fails to Stir Indonesia
item.description: The film recounts in graphic detail the killings of an estimated 500,000 or more Indonesians during state-sponsored purges of suspected Communists and their sympathizers in 1965 and 1966.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Joshua Oppenheimer, the American director of the Indonesian film "The Act of Killing."

item.title: Pro-Hezbollah Song Opens Musical Front in Civil War Over Syria
item.description: Where Sunni and Shiite singers once aimed their barbed lyrics at Israel, they now increasingly target each other.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ali Barakat in his studio in Nabatiye, Lebanon. His song urging Hezbollah to defeat rebels in a Syrian town has angered rebels and Sunnis.

item.title: Amid More Signs of Russian Force in Crimea, Delight Mixes With Dismay
item.description: Russian-speaking armed men fanned out across Simferopol and pro-Russian forces were also said to have taken control of a government building in Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pro-Russian crowd in Simferopol waved a Russian flag in front of a local government building guarded by armed men on Saturday.

item.title: Rise in Bigotry Fuels Massacre Inside Myanmar
item.description: Killings of the Rohingya minority are a test for Myanmar’s government, which has done little to rein in the violence even as it pursues broad economic and political reforms.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Ukraine Finds Its Forces Are Ill Equipped to Take Crimea Back From Russia
item.description: In the autonomous region of Crimea, the Ukrainian military has only a token force with light weapons, and it lacks the country’s advanced battle tanks, a Russian military expert said.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: Andrew Kravchenko/Ukraine Prime Minister Press Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Acting President Oleksandr V. Turchynov, at the left lectern, on Saturday with acting Prime Minister Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, at the right lectern.

item.title: Kremlin Deploys Military in Ukraine, Prompting Protest by U.S.
item.description: As Russian forces effectively seized control of Ukraine’s Crimean peninsula, the Russian Parliament granted President Vladimir V. Putin the authority he sought to use military force in response to the instability in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Armed men guard a government building in Simferopol, in the Crimea region of Ukraine on Saturday.

item.title: Missions Signal a Growing Role for Mormon Women
item.description: After the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints lowered its age requirement for female missionaries in October 2012 to 19 from 21, the thousands of women who have signed up are expected to fundamentally alter this most American of churches.
item.category: Mormons (Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints)
item.dc:creator: By JODI KANTOR and LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicolle Ensign, center, and Victoria Julayne Scott, Mormon missionaries, talked with a potential recruit in South Korea.

item.title: Orchestrated Knife Attacks Kill 27 at Chinese Rail Station
item.description: A group of assailants, dressed in black and wielding knives, stormed into a train station in Kunming in southwestern China, slashing employees and commuters.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Outside a railway station in Kunming in southwestern China, where assailants killed at least 27 people and wounded 106.

item.title: Opinion: Soviet-Era Sex Ed
item.description: My daughter is getting much more detailed information in a school course.
item.dc:creator: By LARA VAPNYAR

item.title: Violence in Iraq Killed 703 in February, U.N. Reports
item.description: The figures issued by the United Nations’ mission to Iraq is close to January’s death toll of 733, showing that a surge of violence that began 10 months ago with a government crackdown on a Sunni protest camp is not receding.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Memo From Kiev: After Initial Triumph, Ukraine’s Leaders Face Battle for Credibility
item.description: Successful revolutions, as the interim government in Kiev has been learning, are a lot harder to maintain than it can seem in the bright dawn of first victories.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: News Analysis: Making Russia Pay? It’s Not So Simple
item.description: President Obama has warned Russia that “there will be costs” for a military intervention in Ukraine. But the U.S. has few options for imposing such costs, and recent history has shown that Russia has been willing to absorb any such fallout.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Pampered Guests and Feuding Hosts at Claridge’s Hotel
item.description: British and Irish magnates are squabbling over the ownership of Claridge’s, the London luxury hotel.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The entrance to Claridge’s, long known as a retreat for monarchs and celebrities.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Crackdown on Baby Trafficking Zeros In on Websites
item.description: The police have broken up four online businesses that matched prospective adoptive parents with children needing homes — in reality, baby traffickers, the police said. Some of the sites posed as public welfare interest groups, or disguised the babies as “gold jewelry.”
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A woman holds a candle behind a board displaying photos of missing children. The Chinese police said they rescued 382 babies in an operation that broke up four major Internet-based baby-trafficking rings.

item.title: The Lede: Feb. 28 Updates on the Crisis in Ukraine
item.description: Video of entire news conference by Viktor F. Yanukovych; ousted president’s Swiss bank accounts frozen.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Ukraine's ousted president, Viktor Yanukovych, speaking Friday at a news conference in Russia.

item.title: World Briefing: American Envoy to Syria Steps Down
item.description: The United States’ top representative to the Syrian opposition, Robert S. Ford, retired from the Foreign Service on Friday, the State Department said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: With Military Moves Seen in Ukraine, Obama Warns Russia
item.description: The new Ukrainian government claimed that Russia was trying to provoke a military conflict by sending troops to Crimea, while President Obama warned Russia to respect Ukraine’s sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN, MARK LANDLER and ALISON SMALE
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Armed men patrolled the street outside Simferopol’s airport in the Crimea region of Ukraine on Friday.

item.title: South Korea Assails Japan on Wartime Brothels
item.description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea urged Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan to acknowledge Japan’s 20th-century aggressions.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Valery Kubasov, 79, Russian Who Helped Bring Cold War Thaw to Space, Is Dead
item.description: Mr. Kubasov was a cosmonaut when a Soyuz spaceship linked with an Apollo capsule in 1975, some 140 miles above the earth.
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD GOLDSTEIN
item.media:description: Lt. Col. Aleksei A. Leonov, left, and Valery N. Kubasov.

item.title: Effort to Delay Terror Trial of a Bin Laden Relative Fails
item.description: The terrorism trial of Sulaiman Abu Ghaith will not be delayed despite a claim by his lawyers that authorities may have mixed him up with a detainee at Guantánamo Bay with a similar name.
item.dc:creator: By BENJAMIN WEISER
item.media:description: Lawyers in a terrorism case have sought testimony from Khalid Shaikh Mohammed.
